questions.text: During a laparoscopic intra-abdominal surgery, the surgeon has to insufflate the peritoneal cavity. Which of the following statements is true regarding the Veress needle technique?

options.label: A
options.text: It is an open technique for creating pneumoperitoneum

options.label: B
options.text: The positioning of the needle is confirmed by a laparoscopic camera

options.label: C
options.text: Veress needle is a spring-loaded needle

options.label: D
options.text: It has a sharp inner stylet that deploys in the peritoneal cavity

questions.correct_answer: C. Veress needle is a spring-loaded needle
questions.explanation:
Closed technique

Open technique

  • Veress needle and/or visual entry trocar (Option A)
  • The Veress needle is a spring-loaded needle (Option C). It has:
    • An outer sharp bevel that cuts.
    • A spring-loaded blunt inner stylet (Option D) deploys once it enters the peritoneum and protects from injuries to the bowel and vessels.
  • Inserted at the umbilical region or other sites like Palmer’s point.
  • Once position is confirmed (by the hanging drop method or abdominal pressure reading of <10mmHg), CO2 insufflation is started slowly until a pressure of 12-15mmHg is reached.
  • The needle is then removed, and an optical primary port is placed.
 

Veress needle:


 
  • Hasson’s or modified Hasson’s
  • Umbilicus is the preferred site for a 10-12mm initial port placement.
  • A blunt-tipped 10 to 12-mm trocar is pushed through an incision made through the decussation inferior to the cicatrix of the umbilicus.
  • The laparoscopic camera is used to confirm the successful placement. (Option B)
  • Then CO2 gas insufflation is started at low flow (1-4 litres per minute)
  • Increased to a maximum pressure of 15 mmHg with a maximum flow rate of 20L/min.
 

Trocar:

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient undergoes bariatric surgery and is at risk for postoperative complications. What is the most common cause of 30-day mortality following bariatric surgery?
questions.explanation:
Overall mortality rates

Perioperative mortality for bariatric surgery is low (<0.5%) and declining but can reach 2.0% or higher in some patient groups.

Common causes of 30-day mortality after bariatric surgery
  • Pulmonary embolism (38%) (Option B)
  • Cardiac failure (18%) (Option A)
  • Anastomotic leak (18%) (Option C)
  • Respiratory failure (12%) (Option D)

Most dreaded complication

Anastomotic leak with overall morbidity of 61% and mortality of 15%.

Maximum risk of anastomotic leak

Gastrojejunal anastomosis (60-80%)

Comparison across procedures
  • Mortality rates for laparoscopic procedures were reported as:
  • Laparoscopic adjustable gastric banding: 0.06%,
  • Vertical band gastroplasty: 0.21%,
  • Roux-en-Y gastric bypass: 0.16%,
  • Biliopancreatic diversion with duodenal switch: 1.11%.
  • Higher mortality rates were found for open procedures compared to laparoscopic ones.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with a BMI of 38 kg/m² is considering weight loss surgery. The surgeon suggests a procedure that involves placing a band around the stomach just below the cardia to create a small gastric pouch. Which procedure is being recommended?
questions.explanation:
Popularity decline

Due to long-term results and alternatives.

Procedure
  • Uses the pars flaccida technique through the window of the lesser omentum.
  • Band Placement: Positioned just below the esophagogastric junction to create a small virtual gastric pouch.
  • Band Fixation: Sutured anteriorly with gastrogastric tunneling sutures to prevent slippage.
  • Access Port: Sutured to the rectus sheath in the upper abdomen for easy access by a non-coring, Huber needle for adjustments.

Types of adjustable bands
  • Lapband (silicon)
  • SAGB

Image

Mechanism of action

Purely restrictive bariatric procedure. Reduces hunger, likely through vagal mediation.

Treatment approach
  • Initial Placement: Marks the start of treatment, requiring ongoing management.
  • Band Adjustments: Involves specialist consultations to assess eating habits and then perform adjustments with injection or aspiration of saline to achieve optimal appetite control.

Challenges

Requires frequent adjustments, associated with patient frustration and lower compliance, impacting long-term weight loss.

Follow up

Monthly visits are recommended for the first year, with full multidisciplinary team (MDT) support.

Complications

Early:

  • Access port infection (1%)
  • Deep vein thrombosis(DVT)/ Pulmonary embolism (PE)(<0.1%)

Late:

  • Band infection
  • Tubing leak
  • Slippage
  • Erosion into stomach
  • Band intolerance
  • Failure to lose weight/weight regain

Method

Minimally invasive, temporary procedure with an endoscopically placed balloon filled with saline or air into the stomach.

Mechanism

Balloon serves as a restrictive mechanism and promotes the feeling of satiation as it is a space-occupying device.

Volume of balloon needed

A 400 mL balloon or larger can effectively induce satiation.

Effectiveness

Can achieve 6-15% total body weight loss compared to lifestyle modification alone.

FDA-Approved Balloons
  • Obalon,
  • Orbera,
  • ReShape.

Adverse Effects

Common adverse effects: Pain, nausea, GERD, gastric ulcers, balloon migration

Serious adverse effects: Small bowel obstruction, perforation, death.

Patient Compliance

Essential for success;

Requires adherence to lifestyle modifications.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman with a BMI of 40 kg/m² undergoes sleeve gastrectomy. Post-surgery, she asks how the procedure helps her lose weight. What is the primary mechanism by which sleeve gastrectomy leads to weight loss?

options.label: A
options.text: Reduced stomach size and hormonal changes.

options.label: C
options.text: Reduced appetite with no hormonal impact.

options.label: D
options.text: Nutrient malabsorption due to intestinal bypass.

questions.correct_answer: A. Reduced stomach size and hormonal changes.
questions.explanation:
Sleeve gastrectomy

A recent, safe and effective surgical technique and a leading method in metabolic surgery for treating obesity with higher survival rates.

Procedure

  • Involves resection of a large part of the stomach, which regulates appetite.
  • Does not require gastrointestinal anastomosis or intestinal bypass.
  • Minimally invasive and less technically challenging.

Image

Mechanism of weight loss (Option A)

Weight loss is achieved through both mechanical restriction (reduction of stomach size) and hormonal modulation (affecting hunger hormones such as ghrelin).

Uses

  1. Weight Loss
  2. Reduce mental health problems
  3. Clinical Markers: Improve serum lipid profile, biochemical, histological, hematological and inflammatory markers.
  4. Obesity-related disease resolution: Better control of Type 2 diabetes, non-alcoholic fatty liver disease, cardiovascular risk, obstructive sleep apnea and stroke risk.
  5. Non-obesity related disease remission: Reduced gout attacks, musculoskeletal pain, improved fertility and reduced pregnancy complications and lower cancer incidence.

Complications

Early

  • Leak at angle of His (1-2%)
  • Intra-abdominal bleed (2-3%)
  • Deep vein thrombosis(DVT)/ Pulmonary embolism (PE)(<1%)

Late

  • Nutritional: Iron, vitamin B12, calcium,vitamin D deficiency
  • Gastro-oesophageal reflux
  • Barrett's esophagus
  • Weight regain

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman is recovering from a recent Roux-en-Y gastric bypass surgery. She has been informed about the possible complications that can arise post-surgery. Which of the following is least likely to be a complication of her bypass surgery?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Mini-Gastric Bypass

Roux-en-Y Gastric Bypass

Procedure

Involves a longer tubular gastric pouch and then the distal end of the pouch is connected to jejunum about 150-250 cm from the ligament of Treitz.

Involves the creation of a small gastric pouch from the proximal end of the stomach, which is then connected with the distal jejunum. Roux limb is varied between 100-150 cm.

Weight loss

Weight loss is by both restrictive and malabsorptive.

Image

No. of Anastomosis

One:

  • Gastro-jejunal anastomosis

Two:

  • Gastro-jejunal anastomosis
  • Jejunal-jejunal anastomosis

Complications

Early:

  1. Anastomotic leak (<1 %) (Option A)
  2. Intra-abdominal bleed (2-3%)
  3. Unspecified obstruction (1-2%)
  4. Deep vein thrombosis(DVT)/ Pulmonary embolism (PE) (<1%) (Option D)

Late:

  1. Internal hernia (Option B)
  2. Chronic abdominal pain
  3. Malnutrition if long limb bypass; Iron deficiency anemia; Vitamin B12 deficiency; Calcium deficiency
  4. Anastomotic ulcer/ stricture

options.label: A

options.label: D
options.text: Patients with artificial prostheses are less prone to nosocomial infections than those with indwelling devices.

questions.correct_answer: B. Klebsiella is a frequent cause of drug-resistant hospital-acquired UTIs.
questions.explanation:
Hospital Acquired Infections:
  • Acquired infections after 48 hours of hospital admission that were neither present nor incubating at the time of admission.
  • Spread by healthcare workers or between patients if aseptic measures are not followed.

High-Risk Patients
  • Diabetics
  • Immunosuppressed individuals
  • Patients on steroids, life-supporting machines.
  • Instrumentation (indwelling catheter, IV cannula, tracheostomy tube)
  • Patients with artificial prostheses

Common Pathogens
  • Wound infection: Staphylococcus aureus (most common), Pseudomonas, Klebsiella, E.coli, Proteus.
  • Respiratory tract infections: Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus, Herpes, Varicella, Aspergillus, Pneumocystis carinii.
  • UTIs: Klebsiella (most common).
  • Antibiotic-associated diarrhea: Clostridium difficile.

Management

Most organisms invading are multidrug-resistant and virulent and hence cause severe sepsis.

  • Antibiotics based on culture results.
  • Blood, urine, pus for culture and sensitivity to isolate the organisms.
  • Supportive care (e.g., ventilator, nutrition, maintaining optimum urine output).

Prevention

  • Isolate infected patients.
  • Follow strict aseptic practices.
  • Disinfect facilities, treat underlying conditions and proper nutrition.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman, 4 days post-abdominal surgery, reports a sudden feeling of popping at her surgical site followed by the drainage of pinkish fluid. On examination, there is partial wound dehiscence with no visible bowel protrusion. What is the next best step in management?

options.label: B
options.text: Apply a wound vacuum system and monitor

options.label: D
options.text: Place an abdominal binder and observe

questions.correct_answer: A. Prompt reclosure of the fascia
questions.explanation:
Wound Dehiscence

Disruption of any or all of the layers in a wound.

Occurrence

Up to 3% of abdominal wounds; most commonly occurs between the 5th and 8th postoperative days.

Types

  1. Partial dehiscence: Involves only the skin and subcutaneous fat.
  2. Complete dehiscence: Involves the fascial layer and may include evisceration (extrusion of abdominal viscera).

Risk Factors

General:

  • Malnourishment
  • Diabetes
  • Obesity
  • Renal failure
  • Jaundice
  • Sepsis
  • Cancer
  • Treatment with steroids
  • Emergency surgery

Local:

  • Inadequate or poor closure of wound or closure of a wound under tension
  • Poor local wound healing
  • Increased intra-abdominal pressure

Clinical Presentation
  • Pinkish serosanguinous discharge (salmon-coloured fluid),
  • Possible evisceration,
  • Popping sensation during straining or coughing.

Treatment

  • Partial dehiscence (without evisceration): Prompt reclosure of the fascia is generally advised. (Option A)
  • Complete dehiscence with evisceration:
  • Requires urgent reoperation.
  • Tension suturing is done.
  • Protect eviscerated bowel with moist towels; handle carefully to prevent injury.
  • Antibiotic therapy; fluid management.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man develops a fever of 101.5°F on postoperative day 5 after total hip replacement. He also has localized pain and swelling in his left calf. The chest X-ray is normal, and there are no respiratory symptoms. What is the most likely cause of his fever?
questions.explanation:
Causes of Postoperative Fever

Immediate Fever: Fever occurs immediately after surgery or within hours on postoperative days (POD) 0 or 1.

  • Malignant Hyperthermia
  • Bacteremia
  • Gas gangrene of the wound (Option D)
  • Febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reaction

Acute Fever: Fever occurs in the first week (POD 1 to 7).

  • POD 1: Pyretic response to surgery
  • POD 3: Unresolved atelectasis resulting in pneumonia; development of urinary tract infection (UTI)
  • POD 5: Thrombophlebitis (Option B)
  • POD 7: Pulmonary embolism (Option A)
  • POD 7 (5 to 10): Wound infection

Subacute Fever: Fever occurs between postoperative weeks 1 and 4.

  • POD 10: Deep infections (Option C)
  • Drugs reactions

Delayed Fever: Fever after >4 weeks.

  • Skin and soft tissue infection (SSTI)
  • Viral infections

questions.text: A 50-year-old man develops sudden respiratory distress, altered consciousness and hypotension during a craniotomy surgery. The anesthesiologist hears a mill-wheel murmur and suspects an air embolism. What is the most appropriate immediate action?
questions.explanation:
Air Embolism

Occurs when air enters accidentally into the vascular system.Commonly iatrogenic via interventional procedures, but also from trauma, diving, childbirth, and other circumstances.

Causes

  • Through venous access like IV cannula.
  • Artificial Pneumothorax.
  • Surgeries of neck and axilla.
  • Traumatic opening of major veins sucking air inside.
  • Fallopian tube insufflation.
  • Laparoscopic surgeries.
  • Illegal abortions.

Symptoms
  • Respiratory Distress,
  • Hemoptysis,
  • Convulsions,
  • Unconsciousness,
  • Visual and hearing disturbances,
  • Fatigue and numbness,
  • Paralysis,
  • Hemodynamic instability,
  • Coma.

Diagnosis

  • Patient history especially relation to recent procedures.
  • Auscultation: Millwheel murmur heard over the precordium is diagnostic.
  • ECG: ST depression and right heart strain due to pulmonary artery obstruction.
  • Capnometry: Decreased end-tidal CO2 levels in intubated patients.
  • Imaging: Chest X-ray, Doppler ultrasonography, transesophageal echocardiography (TEE).

Treatment

  • Positioning:
  1. Trendelenburg position: Keeps air bubbles away from coronary arteries.(Option C)
  2. Left lateral decubitus position: Helps trap air in the non-dependent segment of the right ventricle, preventing it from entering the pulmonary artery.
  • Hyperbaric oxygen therapy: Useful in both venous and arterial air embolism as it reduces ischemia, bubble size; in arterial embolism it removes nitrogen from bubbles to improve perfusion and oxygenation.
  • Aspiration: Air should be aspirated from the right ventricle with a needle.
  • Open Thoracotomy: Life-saving procedure required to aspirate excess air causing the block.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female patient is scheduled for lateral thoracotomy. The surgical team prepares to position her on the operating table. Which position should the patient be placed in for optimal access to the thorax?
questions.explanation:
Position

Description

Uses and Complications

Supine Position

Most common position for general surgical procedures.

Modifications of Supine position:

  • Rose’s position
  • Shoulder and Arm Extended
  • Trendelenburg Position
  • Reverse Trendelenburg Position
  • Fowler's Position

General surgeries.

Rose's Position

Supine with slight neck extension.

Head and neck surgery.

Shoulder and Arm Extended

Supine with shoulder and arm extended.

Axillary and breast surgery.

Trendelenburg Position

(Option D)

Head end tilted down, knees slightly flexed.

Pelvic procedures, resuscitating patients in shock.

Reverse Trendelenburg Position

Head end tilted upward, placing the head higher than the feet.

Upper abdominal surgeries.

 

Complication: Right shoulder pain due to CO2 collected under the right dome of diaphragm during laparoscopic cholecystectomy

Fowler's Position

Semi-sitting with trunk raised at 40° and knees bent.

Neurosurgery, shoulder surgeries, patients with heart or respiratory failure.

 

Complication: Increased risk of air embolism.

Prone Position

Patient is intubated and log-rolled onto the operating bed with help.

Spinal surgery, extra levator abdominoperineal excision for rectal cancer.

Jackknife Position

(Option A)

(Prone Position Modification)

Chest supported, abdomen relaxed by flexing at the hips.

Provides excellent access to the perineum.

 

Complication: Positional asphyxia

Lateral Decubitus or Kidney Position (Option B)

Lower leg flexed, pillow between legs, upper leg flexed in an exaggerated position.

Draining abscesses, lateral thoracotomy, urological and retroperitoneal procedures.

 

Complication: Increased risk of brachial plexus injury due to hyperextension

Lithotomy Position

(Option C)

Supine with hips and knees flexed, legs in stirrups, hips flexed to 90°.

Gynecological, perineal, and urological procedures.

 

Complication: Common peroneal nerve injury if legs are not supported properly

Lloyd-Davies Position (Lithotomy Modification)

Supine with hips minimally flexed (~15°) and a 30° head-down tilt.

Gynecological, perineal, and urological procedures.

questions.text: Which of the following strategies is most effective in preventing surgical site infections (SSIs) during an operation?

options.label: A
options.text: Administering prophylactic antibiotics before the first incision and maintaining positive pressure in the operating room (OR).

options.label: B
options.text: Using concentric circles for antisepsis application and maintaining the OR temperature at 18 ± 3°C.

options.label: C
options.text: Administering antibiotics after the operation and maintaining a negative pressure differential in the OR.

options.label: D
options.text: Avoiding alcohol-based antiseptic solutions and using antibiotics with a short tissue half-life.

questions.correct_answer: A. Administering prophylactic antibiotics before the first incision and maintaining positive pressure in the operating room (OR).
questions.explanation:
Prophylactic Considerations

Details

Prophylactic Antibiotics

Administered before the first incision to ensure maximal antibiotic levels are present in tissues at the time of incision, reducing the risk of bacterial contamination. (Option C)

Operating Room (OR) Air Pressure

Positive pressure differential in the OR is essential to keep outside air from entering, preventing airborne contamination and reducing the risk of Surgical Site Infections (SSIs). (Option C)

Antisepsis Application Technique

Concentric circles are often used, but WHO guidelines state that the specific pattern (concentric circles, horizontal or vertical) does not significantly impact SSI prevention. (Option B)

Operating Room Temperature

Recommended OR temperature is 21 ± 3°C. A temperature of 18°C is too low, potentially causing hypothermia in patients, negatively affecting wound healing and outcomes. (Option B)

Skin Antisepsis Solution

Alcohol-based solutions like chlorhexidine alcohol are recommended for skin antisepsis because of their effectiveness in reducing transient organisms and preventing SSIs. (Option D)

Antibiotic Selection

Antibiotics with a short half-life might not maintain adequate tissue levels throughout surgery. Long-acting antibiotics or those that can be re-dosed during long surgeries are preferred. (Option D)

questions.text: A 28-year-old man from a resource-poor area presents with a 3-week history of fever, abdominal pain, and altered bowel habits. Abdominal examination reveals a doughy feel and a mass in the right iliac fossa. Which finding would most likely distinguish intestinal tuberculosis from typhoid fever in this patient?

options.label: B
options.text: Positive blood culture for Salmonella Typhi

options.label: C
options.text: Multiple longitudinal ulcers in the terminal ileum

questions.correct_answer: D. Caseating granulomas on intestinal biopsy
questions.explanation:
Feature

Intestinal Tuberculosis

Typhoid (Enteric Fever)

Causative Organism

Mycobacterium tuberculosis

Salmonella typhi

Mode of Transmission

Ingestion of food contaminated with tubercle bacilli

Fecal-oral route

Gross Appearance (Ulcer Description)
  • Ulcers are transverse, often circumferential, forming a "girdle" shape.
  • Typically multiple ulcers.
  • Located mostly in the Ileocaecal region.
  • Ulcers are longitudinal, multiple and arranged in a parallel and antimesenteric pattern.
  • Often occur in the terminal ileum and Peyer's patches.
  • Ulcers can perforate, leading to peritonitis.

Microscopic Features
  • Presence of granulomas with caseating necrosis.
  • Epithelioid cells and Langhans giant cells are common.
  • Lymphoid hypertrophy is noted.
  • Neutropenia and splenomegaly may also be observed.

Clinical Presentation
  • Dull, colicky abdominal pain, often in the right iliac fossa.
  • Weight loss, fever, and anemia are common.
  • Mass may be felt in the right iliac fossa (indicating ileocaecal involvement).
  • Presents initially with fever, chills, and abdominal pain.
  • Severe diarrhea, relative bradycardia, and abdominal tenderness are common.

Complications
  • Intestinal obstruction due to stricture formation.
  • Risk of bowel perforation and fistula formation.
  • Intestinal hemorrhage.
  • Perforation leading to faecal peritonitis.
  • Paralytic ileus is a common complication.

Diagnostic Features
  • Histology: Granulomas, Langhans giant cells and caseating necrosis are diagnostic.
  • IFN-γ release assays
  • Widal test, blood cultures positive for S. typhi.
  • PCR assay for typhoid is also useful.
  • X-ray may show gas under the diaphragm if perforation is present.

Treatment

Anti-tubercular therapy

Antibiotics (e.g., cephalosporins)

questions.text: A 48-year-old male immigrant presents with a painless, fluctuating mass in the neck that has been gradually enlarging over 2 months, along with an evening rise in temperature and weight loss. On examination, there is a 3 cm soft, non-tender swelling in the left posterior triangle of the neck without signs of inflammation. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.explanation:
Category

Details

Causative Organism

Mycobacterium tuberculosis

Common Sites
  • Neck lymph nodes (80%), especially upper deep cervical (jugulodigastric - 54%)
  • Posterior triangle lymph nodes (22%)

Clinical Features
  • Firm, matted lymph nodes
  • Cold abscess formation
  • Sinus formation with yellowish caseating discharge

Gross Pathology
  • Firm, matted lymph nodes with yellowish caseating material on cut section

Microscopic Features
  • Epithelioid cells with caseating material
  • Langhans giant cells

Stages

1. Lymphadenitis: Discrete, firm/hard, mobile, non-tender nodes

2. Matting: Nodes move together en masse due to periadenitis

3. Cold Abscess: Deep to deep fascia

4. Collar-stud Abscess: Rupture through the deep fascia, adherent to skin

5. Sinus Formation: Discharges yellowish caseating material

Types
  • Hyperplastic: 20% cases, discrete, firm, or hard nodes
  • Caseating: 75-80% cases, matted nodes, often with cold abscess
  • Atrophic: Rare, small atrophied nodes, caseating type

Investigation
  • FNAC: Useful for detecting epithelioid cells and Langhans giant cells
  • Ultrasound neck: Node size, matting, cold abscess, and sinus tracking
  • Chest X-ray: To detect associated pulmonary tuberculosis
  • Mantoux test: May be useful but not very reliable
  • CT neck and chest: For nodal status

Treatment
  • Antitubercular Drugs: Rifampicin, INH, Ethambutol, Pyrazinamide (for 6-9 months)
  • Aspiration: Cold abscess is aspirated to prevent sinus formation
  • Incision and Drainage: If abscess recurs
  • Surgical Removal: Indicated if there is no response to drugs or sinus persists

questions.text: A 56-year-old diabetic male presents with severe leg pain, swelling, dusky discoloration, and bullae, 24 hours after a minor cut. The leg is edematous with crepitus, and the patient is febrile and tachycardic, showing signs of septic shock. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.explanation:
Necrotizing fasciitis

It is a severe, rapidly spreading infection that produces necrosis of the subcutaneous tissues and overlying skin associated with significant morbidity and mortality.

Cause
  • Most common: Group A β-haemolytic Streptococci.
  • Occasionally Staphylococcus aureus.
  • Can be polymicrobial, involving Bacteroides, Clostridium, Proteus, Pseudomonas and Klebsiella.

Forms
  • Fournier's gangrene: Affects the perineal area.
  • Meleney's gangrene: Involves the abdominal wall.

Pathology
  • Acute inflammatory infiltrate.
  • Extensive necrosis, edema, and thrombosis of microvasculature.
  • Dusky blue and black skin, bullae and progress to cutaneous gangrene.
  • Rapid spread with possible skip lesions, later coalesce.
  • Accompanied by fever, severe toxicity, and potential renal failure due to septic shock.

Predisposing Conditions
  • Diabetes mellitus,
  • Smoking,
  • Penetrating trauma,
  • Pressure sores,
  • Immunosuppression,
  • Intravenous drug abuse,
  • Perineal infections,
  • Skin damage/infection.

Signs and Symptoms
  • Local:
  • Unusual pain,
  • Erythema, edema, warmth,
  • Crepitus,
  • Blisters, bullae,
  • Grayish drainage (dishwasher pus),
  • Fixed staining,
  • Necrosis, gangrene.
  • Systemic:
  • Fever, tachycardia, tachypnea,
  • Shock,
  • Coagulopathy,
  • Multiorgan failure.

Diagnosis

  • Based on clinical presentation.
  • Elevated creatinine kinase levels.
  • Biopsy of fascial layers confirms diagnosis.
  • Radiographs may show air in tissues.

Management

  • Immediate ICU admission with monitoring of volume status and cardiac function.
  • Administer oxygen; intubate if necessary.
  • High-dose IV penicillin G and broad-spectrum antibiotics (e.g., third-generation cephalosporins, metronidazole).
  • Immediate, aggressive surgical excision with daily dressing changes.
  • Multiple debridements may be needed.
  • Large wounds may require skin grafting or flap coverage.
  • Vacuum-assisted dressings and early skin grafting aid healing and minimize fluid loss. Hyperbaric oxygen therapy can reduce mortality.

Mortality

Between 30% and 50%, even with prompt operative intervention.

Image

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with severe muscle pain and swelling in his leg following a gunshot wound. The wound has a foul-smelling, brown discharge and shows signs of crepitus. X-rays reveal gas in the soft tissues. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Gas Gangrene

A rapidly progressive, potentially fatal condition characterized by widespread necrosis of muscles and soft-tissue destruction, often due to late-presenting missile wounds or crushing injuries.

Cause

Clostridium perfringens

Incubation period

<24 hours but ranges from 1 hour to 6 weeks

Sources and predisposing factors
  • Contaminated soil and feces.
  • Wounds with necrotic or foreign material.
  • Crush wounds, road traffic accidents, amputations.
  • Anaerobic environments in the wound.

Common sites of infection
  • Adductor region of the lower limb and buttocks.
  • Subscapular region in the upper limb.

Clinical features
  • Severe pain with limb swelling rapidly increases in severity.
  • Serosanguineous discharge.
  • Skin turns brown to blue-black with hemorrhagic bullae.
  • Sweet, sticky odor & Soft-tissue crepitus.

Complication

  • Septicaemia, toxemia, renal failure, liver failure.
  • Circulatory failure, DIC, secondary infections.
  • Death occurs in critically ill patients.

Investigation

  • X-ray: Gas in soft tissues.
  • Gram stain & blood culture: Large Gram-positive bacilli without neutrophils.
  • Biochemical profile: Metabolic acidosis, renal failure.
  • Peripheral blood smear: Haemolysis.
  • CT scan for chest or abdominal wounds.

Treatment

  • High-dose intravenous penicillin and clindamycin, along with 3rd generation cephalosporins, are given intravenously.
  • Polyvalent antiserums given intravenously.
  • All dead tissues are excised, and debridement is performed until healthy tissue bleeds.
  • Amputation done in severe cases
  • Hyperbaric oxygen therapy.

Prevention

  • Proper debridement of devitalized crushed wounds.
  • Devitalized wounds should not be sutured.
  • Adequate cleaning of wounds with H₂O₂ and normal saline.
  • Penicillin - As a prophylactic antibiotic.

Image

questions.text: A 55-year-old diabetic male presents with a 2-day history of increasing redness, warmth, and swelling in his left leg and also has fever and chills. The erythema is rapidly expanding, with no clear demarcation. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Erysipelas (Option C)

Cellulitis (Option B)

Carbuncle (Option A)

Definition

Localized, sharply demarcated infection of upper dermis, often with broken skin.

Generalized deeper infection affecting dermis and subcutaneous tissue.

Infection of hair follicles extending into surrounding and subcutaneous tissue.

Cause

Beta-hemolytic Streptococcus pyogenes.

Streptococcus pyogenes, Staphylococcus aureus.

Staphylococcus aureus.

Common Sites

Lower limb, face, ear lobule, orbit.

Lower limb, upper limb, face, scrotum.

Nape of neck, back.

Symptoms

Erythematous, edematous rash; fever, leukocytosis, toxemia; raised rash with sharp margins; serous discharge; Milian's ear sign.

Diffuse expanding erythema, painful, swelling; fever, malaise, toxicity; lymphangitis; no clear edge or limit to infection.

Red, painful nodule; tender, fluctuant lesion; multiple draining sinuses; fever, lymphadenopathy.

Complications

Septicemia, localized gangrene, abscess, pneumonia, meningitis, lymphedema, recurrence (20%).

Pyogenic abscess, bacteremia, septicemia, local gangrene, necrotizing fasciitis.

Septicemia, abscess, necrosis, requiring possible excision or skin graft.

Treatment

Broad-spectrum antibiotics; penicillins, clindamycin; long-term penicillin for recurrence.

Broad-spectrum IV antibiotics; elevation, glycerine-magnesium sulfate dressing.

Control of diabetes; antibiotics; drainage, debridement, possible excision.
